quote: All offenders prepare for   decontamination. Decontamination   will proceed immediately.
Miles Edward O'Brien.
The Argrathi Authority has been   conducting a review of your case.   Do you wish to add anything to the   official record?
No matter.       Your correction is completed. You   are free.
Free?
The crime of espionage requires a   minimum of fifteen cycles of   correction. You've been here for   twenty. It's time for you to go.
But I can't leave. Where would I   go?
That's not my concern.
Remove him.
There. It's done.
Major?
It's me, Chief.
But... it can't be. It's been   twenty years. You haven't changed   at all.
Only a few hours passed during   your correction.
I don't understand.

Chief, I know this is going to be   hard for you to accept, but... you   haven't been in prison. What you   experienced was an artificial   reality, an interactive program   that created memories of things   that never actually happened.
What?
The Major is correct.

We punish our offenders by giving   them memories of incarceration   modelled to fit each offender's   personality. It's more   efficient... and much more   effective than maintaining an   extensive prison system.
Which means everything you think   you experienced in prison,   everything you remember, didn't   happen. It wasn't real.
It was to me, major. It was to   me.
Apparently he got curious about   some Argrathi technology and asked   a few too many questions.   Argrathi security arrested him and   charged him with espionage.
Miles would never break a law   intentionally.
I know that. But by the time the   Argrathi told us what'd happened,   they'd already carried out his   "correction."
Can the memories they implanted be   removed?
The Argrathi claim it's   impossible, but Doctor Bashir will   do his best.
When can I see him?
As soon as Doctor Bashir gives his   okay.
I used to dream about this. Being   on a runabout, coming through the   wormhole, seeing the station   again. I keep expecting to wake   up and find myself back in my   cell.
Being in your cell was the dream.   This is reality.
I forgot how beautiful it was.
Come on. Let's get you home.
Chief?
Julian?
It's really you.
It's me.
He's all yours.
I never thought I'd see you again.
I was pretty worried about you,   too.
Keiko?
She'll see you in a little while.   I want to run some tests first   thing... see what we're up   against.

As for everyone else... they send   their best. They'd be here now,   but I didn't want you to get   overwhelmed. You should take   things easy for a while... Let   yourself get used to the place   again. All right?
Doctor's orders?
Absolutely.
I can't imagine what it must've   been like. Twenty years in that   cell.
It was bad.
In all that time, were you able to   talk to anyone? See anyone?
I was alone.
Eat this.       It's chee'lash fruit. It'll help   you feel better.
Thanks...
I should be the one thanking you.   I've been alone in here for six   cycles.
Six years?
I know. It's a wonder I'm not   insane. But you learn to survive.       Let me guess. Sedition?
Espionage.
It looks like we'll be in here   together for a long time. My name   is Ee'char.
Miles. Miles O'Brien.
Hello, Miles. Welcome to hell.
Completely alone.

The bottom line is... there's not   much I can do. The Argrathi   didn't just install memory   implants. They ran O'Brien   through a time-compressed   simulation of the prison   experience. In his mind, he   actually lived those twenty years.   He reacted to what was happening,   felt pain, fear, hatred, made   choices and decisions that   affected the outcome. And as a   result, those memories are real.   The only way I could get rid of   them would be to wipe his entire   memory clean... and clearly that's   not an option.
I understand.

Listen, Keiko, he's been through   some terrible things in his   life... during the war on Setlik   Three, as a prisoner of the   Paradans, during his trial on   Cardassia Prime. And he's always   survived.    (trying to convince them     both)   In the long run, he's going to be   okay. It's just going to take   time.
(trying to remember how    to do this)   Computer, a piece of chee'lash   fruit please.
Requested item is not on record.   Please provide specifications.
I don't have the specifications.       Cancel the request.
Miles?
I'll leave you two alone.
Oh, Miles.
What's wrong?
You're pregnant.
That's right.
It's been so long... I'd   forgotten.
It's all right, Miles.   Everything's going to be all   right.
I'm done. Can I go color?
Make sure to put your plate in the   replicator.
Do you want to come color with me?
Maybe in a little while.
You did great.
With Molly.
Do you think so?
It must be strange.       To suddenly have a family again.
It's just... I've been alone so   long.
Talking about it with Counselor   Telnorri should help.       Julian says you'll be seeing him   for a while.
Three counseling sessions a week.   I can hardly wait.
Miles?
Uh-huh.
What are you doing?
Nothing.
I mean with your food.
Oh... that. I'm saving it.
Saving it. For what?
For later.

It's just a habit I picked up.       When I was in prison... the guards   didn't much care if I lived or   died. Sometimes they wouldn't   deliver food for days... even   weeks. So when they did get   around to feeding me... I'd eat   as little as possible and save the   rest.
That's horrible.
You get used to it...
I'll clean this up.
You don't have to.
I want to.       I haven't been able to clean   anything in twenty years.
For later.
How'd you manage... six years in   this place all by yourself.
You find ways. I exercise, tell   myself stories, draw Eseekas on   the ground.
Eseekas?
They're geometric patterns.   Drawing them is a way to relax the   body and occupy the mind.
That helps?
It helps me.
Show me how.
It's not easy.
I've got plenty of time to learn.
Here. This is a good spot.
You start by drawing a circle.
Now gaze into the circle.
Do you want to learn or not?
I'm gazing.

(picking up where he    left off)   Relax your mind. Imagine that the   circle encompasses your entire   existence. Let it become part of   you.       Now without thinking about it,   allow your hand to make a mark   inside the circle. Expand on the   mark. Let it grow organically   until it becomes a pattern.
What's so funny?
You look like a reeta-hawk picking   at a corpse.
Awk... Awk...
How can you do that?
Do what?
Laugh... after six years in here.
After six years in a place like   this, you either learn to laugh...   or you go insane.
I prefer to laugh.
All offenders prepare for dormancy   period. Any offender still active   during the dormancy period will be   disciplined. Illumination will be   suspended in twenty seconds.
Quickly.
Sleep well, Miles. And if you   feel like laughing in the middle   of the night... go ahead. I'm a   heavy sleeper.
Dormancy period initiated.
Miles?
Your throw.
Do I need one seventeen, or two?
I'm not sure.
Neither am I.
We could start again.
That's all right. I know darts   isn't really your game. And to be   honest, I don't feel much like   playing either.
We could go kayaking in the   holosuite.
You're a good friend, but...
Excuse me.
Is everything all right?
It's fine. I just thought I saw   someone I used to know.
Interphasic coil spanner.
ODN recoupler.
You got it.
It's a--
Don't tell me. I'll get it.
A... quantum flux regulator.       Mark Three.
Perfect.
Let's go through them again.
Chief, you know this stuff. You   don't have to worry about it.
I don't want to embarrass myself   in front of the repair crews.
Even if you get one wrong, I'm   sure no one'll think anything of   it. You may be a little rusty,   but you're still the chief.
If I'm still the chief... then I   say we go over these again.
Right you are... Chief.
All done here.
That was quick.
I reconfigured the magnetic   waveguides. Saved us the trouble   of replacing the entire unit.
Good as new.       We're about done here. If it's   all right with you, I was going to   dismiss the crew for lunch.
You go ahead. I want to take a   look at a couple of things down   here... brush up a little more.
Keep up the good work, crewman.   In another week or two you'll be   running this place.
And don't you forget it.
Chief... There you are.
Hello, Julian. Here to check up   on me?
To be honest... Yes.       Counselor Telnorri says you   haven't been in to see him in ten   days.
So?
So you're supposed to be seeing   him three times a week.

What for? All Telnorri ever does   is sit there and listen to me tell   stories about what it was like to   be in an Argrathi prison. How   often did they beat me? Was I   distressed by the lack of toilet   facilities?       If you ask me, he's the one with   the problem.
You could talk to a different   counselor. Someone you might like   better.
Julian, I don't want to talk to a   counselor. All I want is to   forget what happened on Argratha   and get on with my life.
Just like that?
That's right. Just like that. I   don't need counseling or   relaxation or time to adjust. I   just want to be left alone.
I would think after being alone   for twenty years you'd want   someone to talk to.

You know, if there was one thing   I didn't miss over the last twenty   years, it was your smug, superior   attitude. Now I said I wanted to   be left alone and I meant it. So   if you know what's good for you   you'll stay the hell away from me.
Tell me about Keiko again. About   how much you like her eyes.
I've told you about her a hundred   times. What more is there to say?
I like hearing about her. If I   had a beautiful wife to talk   about, believe me, I would.   Besides talking about her always   relaxes you. And your pacing is   getting a little distracting.
Well your drawing is bothering me.
Since when?
Since right now.
You didn't need to do that.
Who are you to tell me what I   need?
Miles...
Don't "Miles" me. I'm sick of it.   I'm sick of your drawings, I'm   sick of this place, and most of   all I'm sick of you.
Try to be calm.
I don't want to be calm. I've had   it with this place. I don't   belong here.
Did you hear that? I don't belong   here. I didn't do anything wrong.
I know you're listening.
Get me the hell out of here. I   don't deserve this and you know   it. I didn't do anything wrong.   Let me out.
Miles.
All offenders in detention area   four, if you do not cease this   disturbance immediately, you will   be disciplined.
Discipline this you son of a--
Be quiet before you get yourself   killed.
Chief. How are you doing?
I wish people would stop asking me   that.
I'm sorry, Constable.   Everything's fine. I've just...   had a tough day.
That was a black hole straight up,   right?
A synthale please.
Be right with you, Chief.
Quark. What about that synthale?
Just another minute.
Quark.
Look, Chief, I'm a little busy   right-
I'm in no mood for games, Quark.   So why don't you give me my drink   now or I'll break every bone in   your worthless little body.
Chief, just because your life's in   shambles is no reason--
I mean it.
One synthale coming right up.
But I'm charging you double.
Miles?
Ee'char? What are you doing here?
I've never really been gone, have   I?
You're not real. You're just in   my head.
That's all I ever was. But I'm   real to you and that's all that   matters.
Go away.
I can't. I'm your friend. You   need me.
You're the last thing I need.
You're wrong, Miles. You need me.   Now more than ever.
What are you doing?
Going to work.
Miles, as your friend, I have to   tell you, I'm worried about you.
Don't be. I'm home, I'm working,   and for the first time in as long   as I can remember, I feel good.
Then why am I here?
Sisko to O'Brien. Please report   to my office.
On my way.       Look, I don't know why you're   here. And I don't care.
Have a seat.
I understand you had a   confrontation with Doctor Bashir   yesterday.
That? That was nothing.
Not according to Doctor Bashir.
We had a little argument. Julian   and I are always arguing.
According to Constable Odo, you   also had an incident with Quark.
Did that little--    (catches himself, pulls    back)   Look, Captain...
I know I let things get a little   bit out of hand. But it won't   happen again.
Doctor Bashir also tells me that   you've stopped seeing your   counselor.
I guess I've been a little busy   lately, and--
The agreement was, you were to see   a counselor on a regular basis.
You're right. I'll make an   appointment to go see him   tomorrow.
You'll see him today.   Immediately.
Sir, I've got a lot of work to do   today...
The work can wait.
As of now, you're relieved of duty.
I want you to report to Counselor   Telnorri and begin attending daily   counseling session for as long as   he thinks it's advisable.
You're blowing this all out of   proportion.

You know that's not true. You're   not yourself, Chief. what   happened on Argratha affected you   a lot more than you're willing to   admit. And it's not going to get   better overnight, no matter how   much you want it to. You need   help.
Captain, please. I'm asking you,   as a personal favor to me... give   me one more chance.

I wish I could.       But right now, in the judgement of   this station's chief medical   officer, you're unfit for duty.   Which means you're on medical   leave, effective immediately. And   if you don't begin attending   counseling sessions on a regular   basis, and cooperating in every   other way with your physician, I   will have no choice but to have   you confined to the infirmary. Is   that clear?
Yes, sir.
Dismissed.
Chief, I was just about to head   down to the Replimat and I was   wondering...
Not right now, commander.
Promenade.
What the hell did you say to him?
I take it you talked to Captain   Sisko.
I talked to him all right. And he   relieved me of duty.
It's for the best, Miles.
How would you know what's best for   me? You don't have any idea what   I've been going through.

You're right. You were alone in   that cell. I wasn't there with   you. I didn't see what they did   to you. But I do know you   suffered. And that you're still   suffering right now. And I'm   trying to help.
I never asked for your help.
You didn't have to ask. I'm your   doctor... and your friend.
You should listen to him, Miles.   He cares about you. Just like I   did. Don't make the same mistake   with him that you did with me.
Don't you get it. You're not my   friend. Not anymore. The O'Brien   that was your friend died in that   cell.
He's not dead. He just needs a   little help, that's all.
Stay away from me. I don't want   your help, I don't want your   friendship. I just want to be   left alone.
Where are you going?
I told you to go away.
Miles, please, don't do this. Go   back there and talk to him. He   wants to help.
Like you did?
That's right. We're both your   friends.
Yeah. And look what happened to   you.
Habitat Ring.
You know, sooner or later, you'll   have to tell someone about me.
Like hell I will.
You can't run from me forever.
scene: 66   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CORRIDOR

quote: You're dead. So why don't you   just go away and leave me alone.
You want me to leave? I'll leave.   Send me away.
Don't you see? If I keep coming   back, it's because some part of   you keeps bringing me here.
Miles, Julian's been trying to   contact you for an hour. Where   have you been?
Walking... thinking.
I heard what happened. I'm sorry.   I know how much your work means to   you.
Try telling that to Julian.
Daddy, come see what I drew.
Not right now, honey.
I'm sure this is only temporary.   You'll be back at work before you   know it.
Daddy. You have to come see.
Look, can we talk about this   later?
Daddy, come on.
Not now.
Please, Daddy, please.
I said not now. Don't you hear   what I'm saying? Not now.
Miles.
I didn't mean...
I'm sorry.
Chief?
Get out of here, Julian.
You don't want to do this, Chief.
The hell I don't.
Look, I can't claim to know what   you're going through, but whatever   it is, it's not worth dying for.
You don't understand at all. I'm   not doing this for me. I'm doing   this to protect Keiko, and   Molly... and everyone else on   this station.
Protect us from what?
From me. Don't you get it? I'm   not the same man I used to be.   I'm dangerous.       I almost hit Molly today. Did you   know that? All she wanted was a   little attention and I almost hit   her.
But you didn't. You're a good   man, Miles Edward O'Brien. And   whatever it is you think you've   done wrong, you don't deserve to   die.
You sound like Ee'char.
Who's Ee'char?
He wasn't real. He's a memory...   that's all.
A memory from Argratha.       Who was he? Another prisoner? A   guard?
He was my cellmate.
You told me you were alone in that   cell. Twenty years with no one to   talk to.
Only at the end. A week, maybe   two. But the rest of the time...   there was Ee'char.
What happened to him?
Why did you stop?
It wasn't helping.
You have to concentrate more.
It doesn't matter how much I   concentrate. I'm still starving.
So am I.
You're sure there's nothing left?
Not unless you've got a hiding   place I don't know about.
We ate the last of the food I put   away a week ago.
We should've stockpiled more. We   should've planned for this.
They've never let us go this long   without food before.
What if they've forgotten about   us... or just decided to finally   let us die?
Then we die.
All offenders prepare for dormancy   period. Any offender still active   during the dormancy period will be   disciplined. Illumination will be   suspended in twenty seconds.
What are you doing?
I'm going to sleep.
How can you sleep at a time like   this?
Maybe I'll dream about food.
You're crazy.
No. Just hungry.
Dormancy period initiated.
I knew it.
You pretended to be my friend and   all this time, you've been holding   out on me.
Now who's acting crazy?
After all I've done for you. You   ungrateful...
You were saving it for both of us.
Ee'char?
Ee'char, wake up. Ee'char!
Ee'char.
You killed him?

(a confession to    Ee'char)   And the worst part of it was...   the next day, the guards started   feeding me again. I'd killed him   for nothing... for a scrap of   bread that he was going to share   with me anyway.
It was a mistake. You didn't mean   to do it.
No. I meant it. I wanted him to   die.

I keep telling myself it doesn't   matter. That it wasn't real. But   that's a lie. If it'd been   real... If it'd been you instead   of Ee'char... it wouldn't have   made any difference. He was my   best friend. And I murdered him.       When we were growing up, they used   to tell us that humanity had   evolved.

That mankind had outgrown hate and   rage. But when it came down to   it, when I had the chance to prove   that no matter what anyone did to   me, I was still an evolved human   being, I failed. I paid back   kindness with blood. I was no   better than an animal.

No. An animal would've killed   Ee'char and never had a second   thought, never shed a tear. But   not you. You hate yourself for   it. Hate yourself so much you   think you deserve to die. And   that's what makes you human.       The Argrathi did everything they   could to strip away your humanity.   And in the end, for one brief   moment, they succeeded. But you   shouldn't let that one moment   define your entire life. Because   if you do, if you pull that   trigger, the Argrathi will have   won. They'll have destroyed a   good man. And you can't let that   happen.
Be well, Miles.
Thirty milligrams twice a day.   Take it religiously for a month,   and if everything goes well, we'll   experiment with a lower dosage.
You sure this'll work?
It's a treatment, not a cure.   It'll prevent the hallucinations   and take the edge off the   depression. But that's all it'll   do. It won't take away the   memories... or the feelings.
You mean the guilt.
That'll take time.
Now's the part where you tell me   I have to start seeing Counselor   Telnorri again.
Unless you want to talk to me.
Telnorri will be fine.
Thanks, Julian. For everything.
What are friends for?
Daddy's home, Daddy's home.
That's right, Daddy's home.
